reviewText: Driver Parallel Lines is an amazing driving game from reflections, This game has a brilliant storyline and character development. The driving is so smooth and enjoyable in this game that i can just sit back and cruise 1970s New York listening to amazing songs. That brings me to my next point, the soundtrack. The soundtrack in this game is phenomenal, with the likes of David Bowie and War in the 1978 soundtrack plus the Audio bullys and Yeah Yeah Yeahs in the 2006 soundtrack. The cars are brilliant in this game, they are all easy on the eye (especially the Cerrano, Zartex and the Andec) Overall this game is brilliant, it derserves praise. so called 'PRO' reviewers like Gamestop sicken me with thier review calling the story flat""

reviewText: Driver Parallel Lines is to the 70s what Grand Theft Auto Vice City is to the 80s. Just a hands down fantastic soundtrack to go along with racing and workin' for da man. I thought the campaign story turned out to be really good, although the majority of side missions are pretty weak. The ability to teleport using the map to any location is a really nice feature and takes out the mundaneness of driving long distances. The steering and car handling is a little over-sensitive, but just takes a little patience and practice. For an older game, Parallel Lines has aged fairly well and there's still plenty of moxy left in it--quite enjoyable and certainly a game worth finishing.

reviewText:

reviewText: This game is soo underrated, it's so sad you may be more familiar with the sequel Driver: San Francisco, but this game is more than worth a try. Althou, as a veteran of the Driver series you may notice that many of the game content is from Driv3r, like sounds, physics and the entire engine. But that is not a bad thing, Driv3r was a very good game in it's time, it was just pulled down by the fact that it was a kind of a GTA ripoff. Driver: Parallel lines instead goes back to the Driver-roots. This game shines with an well sold storyline with an intensional twist and good drving-physics, in deneral the atmosphere is very believeable. Personally I'd like more cars like the Cerrano with an awesome V8-sound, but that's just a personal opinion. Overall a very good game and a must for all Speed Junkies/Diver-fans/car enthusiasts.

reviewText:
So firstly off the bat I should say I have WAY more playtime on this, but I recently bought it on Steam and haven't played that much, so don't go ''OMG u only haev 2 hrs, wtf m8'' on me.
So. Driver® Parallel Lines.
This was one of the first games I ever played on my computer and I absolutely adored it.
It is one of the most underrated Driver games, and I recently even saw some hate on it which was really unecessary to be honest, cus this is one of my favorites from the Driver series.
So the price is in fact aswell really low and I think you should get it, cus it's worth it.
Now, let's go over the pros and cons:

Pros:
-Open World
Meaning you can explore the city of New York, which has neighbourhoods that exist in real life (Bronx,Queens,etc)
-A SH*TLOAD of cars
About 94/95 vehicles in this game, including bikes and cars.
-Customization
Well, almost all (if not all) of the 94/95 vehicles are highly customizable, ranging from 4 (5 in some cases) custom bodyworks with paintjobs (or without) , accessories (tinted windows, bulletproof tires and glass) , colours (4/5 default, also there's an option for custom colors, making it with the ''RED,GREEN,BLUE'' filter), nitrous, upgrades to engines,brakes,acceleration and such (almost like the pre-GTA V, GTA V)
-Loads of weapons
Well by loads I mean about 11 or 12. So yeah. Loads.
-Vast enviroment
The enviroment is actually giving a sense of life with people doing casual thing such as buying donuts at stands or jacking cars. No NPC police chases tho. Shame.
-Graphics
Now yes, graphics. This sh*t looks mighty fine for an '07 game dude, like really good.
-Cheats
There are some cheats which can spice up the gameplay. There is the usual godmode cheat, the ''all vehicles in garage'' cheat (same for guns) and it actually kinda makes the game better. About 9/10 great cheats, I think.
-Story
Now yes the story is divided into two different timezones. 1978 and 2006.Both offer new vehicles and weapons along with missions. The missions are both fun and most importantly not just stuff to fill the gaps in between the timezones. The cutscenes are quite a bit different from the graphics of the real game but they look nice so I don't really care
-Thrill Cam
So yea that's a cam which goes into this ''Thrill'' mode and just thrills the sh*t out of my cam. Nifty stuff.
-The soundtrack
Oh the soundtrack. One of the best I've ever seen. Its like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥ but for your ears. An eargasm.
Get it? Get it? Mah f*ck you too then.

Cons:
-Bugs
A few minor bugs such as getting stuck on a f*cking lightpost. Nothing game-breaking tho.

To this 8-year old masterpiece, I give a 10/10. One of my top 10 games of all time.

reviewText: This game is awesome. Never board whether its in 1978 or 2006. This game is definently is a blast from the past literally. Everyone says this is kind of a GTA clone but heres the facts. Driver games have always been like this since the 1990s. The free roam has always been with the Driver series and to be honest the Driver series has always been great. This game is alot of fun. Car costumizing is pretty fun the races can be fun. The controls are decent just be careful and don't over steer on corners. Theres a good selection of cars and the plot line is done pretty well. Driver games have always had a rather unique story line. This game is well worth the money to buy. 10/10.

reviewText:
Though i just bought the game, i have played it when it came out on the console when it came out and i will honestly say this is a truly fantastic game thats definatly under rated.  The game when it came out of its time definatly rivaled Gta. Despite not being able to use planes or helicopters it ain't no problem.  The amount of hours just messing about and happy with the meyhem it kept on achiving. The story is fantastic im not gunna lie if you havn't played it before you'll be hooked on it. The damage of the cars is brilliant a good follow on from driver 3 ( yup even driver 3 had boss damage uber old game now!)

So the pros are:
Thrilling story which will blow your mind. With the era of 1978 and 2006 ( which after completing the game you can swap back and forth.
Damage physics of the cars
Guns
Big map to free roam
endless hours of meyhem
explosions
fantastic graphics ( yes its 2007, 2007 these graphics were the bee's knees.)
tons of side missions ( if i can remember)
cheats ( yup kewl cheats)
can custom cars!!! ( lotta cars)
It even has a spedo in the game!!!
Boss songs/ soundtracks ( few are my personal fav's to this day!)
The cutscenes are so dam awesome highly graphical!

Con's:
speedo should not have a limit
more custom options,
needs more open spaces
no aircraft

But if you don't give a toss about the cons like me then go get it its a bargin and im feeling nostalgia!!

SOLID 9.5 out of 10

reviewText:
Driver Parallel Lines was released at a time where it was trying to outshine it's predecessor Driv3r, which was a horrible abomination of a game.

Parallel Lines honestly isn't that bad. It's actually a LOT better then Driv3r, but it lacks a lot of what made the original 2 and even Driv3r good. Namely the Film Director, which added massive replayability to all 3 games. This game, while featuring a much needed improvement to the driving system from the last game, lacked a lot of what made the series stand out and shine years later.

For the price it''s not bad, but you shouldnt be looking for anything particularly good.

reviewText: The best Driver game in my opinion (Haven't played San Francisco yet.) You play as TK a young man who is new to New York City and meets his hero Ray. Ray gives him a shot at the big time and TK goes into crime. He gets betrayed by his fellow criminals on a job and gets put into prison for 28 years. He gets out and wants to get revenge on those who betrayed him. It's a really good game and you'll enjoy it. A huge recommendation from me.\n\nEdit: I have played Driver San Francisco since writing this review and it is now my favourite in the series. This is still worth playing though.

reviewText: This game changed my life when it came out. After DRIV3R there was no telling what the long selling trilogy would do next. Being raised on these games through my childhood and being intensely drawn into 70's music and culture, this game was exactly where I wanted to be. You play as T.K. a getaway driver in New York in 1976. The selling point was that T.K. gets betrayed by his gang of robbers and goes to jail and comes out in 2006, seeking nothing but vengeance and being as sharp behind the wheel as ever. An exciting game with a good story, the best driving physics, great music, and incredible graphics during the cutscenes. Watching time pass in the city, the characters, guns and the vehicles, really created an emotional attachment in this game. The car customization is also a great feature that keeps this game driving.

reviewText:
EDIT: Nah, actually, screw it. This game is just not playable as it keeps crashing.

I'll refrain from any comparison because the first two Driver installements had so much magic in my eyes that Parallel Lines simply can't compete. So, how does it stand on its own?

Rather fine really. It's more of a GTA than a Driver, but it's not a bad thing. Especially when you can drive bikes and helicopters. To this day, the game still looks more than acceptable. I can't say the graphics bothered me, except maybe the face models, which isn't really that important for a driving game.

Now the story is kinda usual. You get betrayed and decide to take your revenge. You know the drill. It just works!

The OST is absolutely fantastic so long as you stick to the seventies. The modern era OST is absolute garbage, which is rather sad in my opinion. Some great stuff got released that year, why did they solely focus on ♥♥♥♥♥♥ electro?

Anyway, let's get to the PC release.
The game is pretty much entirely customizable. It supports up to a 4k resolution, you can edit the graphical options and what not, even the driving sensitivity. Which I heartily recommend if you're playing with a gamepad because the sensitivity is a bit too high. Also, I'd suggest lowering the circulation because you simply can't drive any fast without crashing with the default options.

BUT THEN. The game keeps crashing all of the ♥♥♥♥ing time. Get out of the garage? Crash. Finish a mission? Crash. Failed a mission and wish to restart? Crash. I could go on and on, but you probably get the idea. Luckilly, the game saves automatically everytime you do something. But still, that perpetual crashing really makes finishing the game a chore.

I'd say pick it up on sale, but it's already 5 bucks so yeah, if you need a fix of GTA like, go for it.

reviewText: The music chosen for this game was perfect. Every single track is excellent. Pure hits! The soundtrack alone is worth what I paid for this game. At least for the 70s era part. The 00s era's music they chose is 95% garbage, but it does make it funny sometimes. New York has been created and rendered exceptionally well. The streets, the alleys, the cars, and all other parts of the environment are nicely done. The day and night cycles also look very nice. The cinematics are also done in a film-like fashion, that involves the player from the very beginning. All characters portrayed are quite interesting, and their voice acting is outstanding. Driver: Parallel Lines has the perfect mood, atmosphere, setting, sounds, and interactions to make you feel like you are truly in the game. Controlling any of the vehicles can be close to impossible without crashing them and eventually making them a complete loss. You will lose control of the vehicles easily. This makes the idea of spending money to upgrade cars you own almost completely wasteful and pointless. The game is extremely difficult. I've had to do missions many, many, many times over until I was successful. The untameable vehicle controls are to blame, in conjunction with the sometimes necessary simultaneous shooting. Repeating many of the missions over, and over, and over gets frustrating, repetitive, and extremely annoying. Often, it is infuriating how unforgiving the game is, with its control and handling issues. The speedometer keeps track of the total amount of miles you have traveled in-game, which is not useful, but pretty cool. Mouse sensitivity in the menus is horrible. Making changes in the settings will do little to make the menus useable by your mouse. Expect to choose menu options with the keyboard. The save system is based on completed missions. So, if you quit during the second part of a five parts mission, for example, you will be forced to start the mission from the very beginning next time you load the game, which is ridiculous. All vehicles take visible damage as you drive around the city like a complete lunatic, with very little care for public safety or your own. The chases and crashes are intense and look straight out of a Hollywood movie. The missions are diverse, challenging, exciting, and agitated even though this is primarily a driving game. Investing money into your owned vehicles and altering them is not forced upon the player, with the exception of one mission. Certainly, if you do buy upgrades, your driving will be temporarily made easier and better, but this is totally optional. Especially because money is hard to come by, and the upgrades or parts are expensive. Spend your money on ammunition instead. Several missions involve precision vehicular platform gaming. This means that you will have to slowly and carefully steer your car on ramps and other on ground structures. There are often hilarious AI controlled accidents that occur throughout the game. Because the missions are so difficult to complete successfully, you will develop hate for your enemies and the police. When you finally defeat them, you will rejoice in glory and relief. If you have much patience, and can forgive the game's excessive difficulty and problematic controls and handling, this is a great game. You will experience excitement, variety, and lots of fun. After the campaign is beaten, several vehicles are unlocked and put into your garage. You are also free to roam New York in both eras and do the money making side missions.\n\nDriver Parallel Lines is great.

reviewText:
I remember back in '08 my dad got this game on his Direct2Drive when it was still a thing. 4 gbs. So I had to wait until the next day to play it. #BurgerInternet. I woke up the next morning ready to play it, but I had to catch my bus in like 10 minutes. I start the game. Controls not set. So I got on the bus waited all day just to play it. When I finally got home, my friend came over and we played it for a good 4 hours then it was 7pm and getting dark then he had to go home. I absolutley love this game.

-Pros
-Good Driving
-Good Gunplay
-Music is fantastic
-Everything Else

-Cons
-None.

reviewText: IT'S JUST AMAZING! not the best graphics in the world but they aren't the worst either. car machanics are amazing and very well done! car customisation is beautifull. there are even different era's in this game! the story line is a bit weird because of that but if that would be amazing as ♥♥♥♥ the mechanics would probably be 10 times worse. this game really is worth the time (and the 4,99 price tag XD). so if you are looking for a fun game to play when you are bored this would be a really good one :) . i really would like to see a sequal.

reviewText: Drive Parallel Lines is a spin-off of the Driver franchise developed by Ubisoft and Reflections Interactive, the game is a third person shooter plus driving game set in a universe which is set in the 70's up to 2006 as your character called T.K (The Kid) looks for a job as a Getaway Driver and begins his career as both a criminal and a copper. Featuring a completely open world similar to the Grand Theft Auto series and it's shooting mechanics return from both Driv3r and inspired by GTA, this game is considerably a competent title worth the purchase.\n\nThe only issues is that there free-aim is fairly limited.

reviewText: Well, what do i have to say about this game??? It is fun when you can play it, but i have tried for countless hours to play this game without it crashing, i have have tried playing it on 3 diffrent computers, some old, some new, and i have tried to find diffrent fixes, but none of them work. Lets list a few of the instances when your game has a chance of crashing, it can crash when you restart a mission or level, when you go to the main menu, when you boot up the game, when you era switch, or just randomly during a game session. I have no idea why this is happening because i am over the minium system requirements to play this game, and i don't know why there are so little reports of this happening, AND i dont know why this isnt being patched... So if you want to play this game, play it on the playstation or xbox, dont waste your money here...
